title: Schedule
text:
The JHU Data Analytics and Policy Hackathon will be held at the Hopkins Bloomberg Center at 555 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20001.
Friday, April 10
11:00am - noon: Check in
Noon: Lunch, opening comments, and organization
1:00 - 3:00pm: Work Session 1
3:00 - 3:30pm: Snacks and status updates
3:30 - 6:00pm: Work Session 2
6:00 - 7:00pm: Dinner and featured speaker Robin Ghertner
7:00pm and onwards - continue your work as needed, then get some rest.
Saturday, April 11
9:00am: light snacks and coffee, opening announcement
9:30 - noon: Work Session 3
Noon to 1:30pm: Lunch and featured speaker Lula Chen
1:30 - 3:00pm: Final preparations
3:00 - 5:00pm: Presentations and closing

title: DAP | HACK 2026
text:
We face a crisis in contemporary politics and government. In the United States and around the world, lived experience and study after study show that many citizens have lost confidence in the ability of government and the public sector to identify and address pressing challenges. From public health to migration to climate and everything in between, the public sector faces a doubting citizenry.
To address public problems, we will need skilled analysts who can quickly process data, gather insights, and make recommendations to policymakers. That is the purpose of the Johns Hopkins University Data Analytics and Policy Hackathon (DAP | HACK 2026). For two days in April, we will convene teams of JHU graduate students, who will bring the tools of data science to bear, demonstrating how these skills can help identify problems and motivate solution frameworks.
The Hackathon is supported through the generosity of the Johns Hopkins University Nexus Grants.

title: Collaborators
text:
We are pleased to welcome a number of outside collaborators who are supporting our event through their scholarship and professional support. Along with the Hackers and Conveners, we please to welcome our featured speakers, project consultants, and judges.
This list is under construction and more names will be added!

title: Collaborators
text:
Featured Speakers



Robin Ghertner
Robin Ghertner is Founding Director of Strategic Policy Intelligence at the Child Welfare Wonk. At the Wonk, he leads efforts to use data and analysis to provide unique insight for decision-makers, advocates, and analysts working on child and family policy. Prior to this project, Robin had a 20-year career in federal and local government. Most recently, Robin was the Acting Associate Deputy Assistant Secretary and Director of the Division of Data and Technical Analysis in the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, within the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Before his time at HHS, Robin was a senior research analyst and lead statistician in the Office of Research and Evaluation at AmeriCorps. In this role, Ghertner led a portfolio of research on improving grant-making processes, grantee community impact, and national service member outcomes. Prior to working for the federal government, Robin provided direct services in New York City in various capacities. Among other projects, he implemented the nation’s largest translation and interpretation policy for the NYC Department of Education, and directed a social service program for immigrants in Queens.





Lula Chen
Lula is the Research Director at MIT GOV/LAB, where she currently works on projects about trust, public goods, technology in government, and Covid-19, often focusing on the roles and attitudes of bureaucrats. She specializes in policy evaluation using randomized controlled trials, causal inference, and quantitative methods. She also studies how individual biases affect group decision-making in foreign policy. During her doctoral studies, she served as a Methods Specialist with the Office of Evaluation Sciences at the U.S. General Services Administration and conducted research on taxation and public service delivery in Malawi as a part of the EGAP Metaketa Initiative. Prior to starting her PhD, she was a program manager at Sister Cities International for U.S.-Chinese-African trilateral municipal cooperation projects. Lula holds a BSFS in Comparative Studies and an MA in Security Studies from Georgetown University. She received her PhD in Political Science from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

title: Collaborators
text:
Project Consultants



Pete Lawson
Pete Lawson is the Data and Visualization Librarian in Data Services at the Johns Hopkins University Sheridan Libraries. Pete has a Ph.D. from Tulane University, where he developed new machine-learning approaches to assess and visualize the presence and progression of prostate cancer in digital histology. As the Data and Visualization Librarian, Pete works directly with researchers to help them find, use, and visualize data. Pete also teaches workshops on data visualization in R and Python.





K’lila Nooning
K’lila Nooning is a data engineer with the Bloomberg Center for Government Excellence at Johns Hopkins University.





Greg LeVay
Greg LeVay is a graduate of the Johns Hopkins University Data Analytics and Policy program. LeVay is a data scientist with the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Agency (CISA). He has experience creating predictive models and generating insights with Python and R.

title: Collaborators
text:
Judges



Jeff Allen
At Johns Hopkins, Jeff Allen is a lecturer for the MS in Data Analytics and Policy program and the recipient of the program’s 2023-24 Excellence in Teaching Award. His research focuses on applying statistical modeling and machine learning to monitor aspects of the global financial system and to evaluate the efficacy of financial innovations. His academic research has appeared in the Journal of Economics and Finance, Business and Politics, PLoS ONE, and the Federal Reserve’s Finance and Economics Discussion Series.
Beyond his role at Johns Hopkins, Allen is a lead analyst at the Federal Reserve Board, where he focuses on payment technology research and financial stability issues. In 2024, he won the Board’s Special Achievement Award for contributions in these areas. Allen previously served as a risk modeling and analytics specialist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. He joined the Fed from the World Bank and previously held a variety of positions in financial public policy.
Allen received a PhD in International Political Economy from Johns Hopkins University.





Pete Damiano
After graduating with a DDS from the UI College of Dentistry, Dr. Damiano served as a commissioned officer in the US Public Health Service’s Indian Health Service, providing dental care to members of the Navajo Nation. He received his MPH and completed his training in health services/policy research in UCLA’s Robert Wood Johnson Dental Health Services Research Scholars Program.
A UI faculty member for 35 years, Dr. Damiano conducts externally-funded health services/policy research focusing on health disparities, including access to and quality of primary care services for underserved populations. He also teaches health policy-related classes in multiple units on campus. He directed the UI Public Policy Center for 15 years, emphasizing the importance of experiential community-based research and public policy education. He is the author of more than 300 journal articles and research monographs and has been principal investigator on more than 90 funded research studies. Dr. Damiano saw dental patients, including special needs adults, in the UI faculty practice for 35 years.





Sarah O’Byrne
Sarah O’Byrne is the Director and a senior lecturer for the Center for Data Analytics, Policy, and Government. She has been teaching in the program since 2007 and currently teaches courses in global political economy, economics for public policy, political economy of development, corruption, and comparative democracies. She received an AAP Excellence in Teaching Award in 2014.
O’Byrne’s research and writing take an interdisciplinary approach that combines political science and economic perspectives and tools. She is currently examining the role of epistemic communities on policy outcomes, specifically in the area of development aid and corruption.
She holds a Bachelor of Arts in economics from Trinity College, Dublin, and a Master of Arts in economics and PhD in political science from Johns Hopkins University.

title: Hackathon Teams
text: Our “hackers” are 25 current and recent JHU graduate students from the MS in Data Analytics and Policy, MS in Applied Economics, and MA in Government programs. Hackers are organized into five teams, each with a different substantive focus connected to our broader event theme.

title: Hackathon Teams
text:
Transparency in Government
This theme explores how governments can make decisions, budgets, and performance visible in ways that feel meaningful and trustworthy to residents. It centers on closing the promise–performance gap by pairing clear reporting with honest communication about uncertainty, trade-offs, and implementation progress. It also grapples with how privacy and security feature in transparency policy. The aim is to show how transparency, when designed for comprehension and accountability, can invite engagement rather than fuel cynicism.


Jay Chok




Jay Chok is a graduate student majoring in Financial Economics at Johns Hopkins University, where he conducts research under Professor Steve Hanke who is a renowned economist, currency board advocate, and former senior economic advisor to President Ronald Reagan. Jay brings a robust technical background to his economic analysis, having earned a Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering from Virginia Tech. Before transitioning to financial economics, he was a Software Product Engineer at Qualcomm in San Diego for 3 years.



Raymond Tam
Hitanshi Garg
Wanyi Zhao
Ming Zhu

title: Hackathon Teams
text:
Energy and Climate Policy
This theme explores building institutional credibility through tangible improvements in affordability, reliability, and resilience, especially for communities facing high energy burdens or the effects of the climate crisis. The work brings together assistance program design, reliability disclosures, and targeted infrastructure investments, linking technical outcomes to perceived fairness and competence. The story is one of energy and climate policy that delivers visible benefits while communicating results in ways people can understand and trust.


Jade Zhou




Jade Zhou is a Master of Public Management student at Johns Hopkins University specializing in fiscal policy and public sector governance. Her research focuses on evaluating the efficiency and accountability of tax incentives, particularly in areas such as clean energy and social programs. She is interested in the intersection of budget design, policy implementation, and institutional trust. Jade aims to pursue roles in policy analysis, public sector consulting, or international development.





Saloni Shah




Saloni K Shah is an MS in Applied Economics student at Johns Hopkins University with over a decade of experience in international development. She has worked as an economist specializing in industrial infrastructure, trade, logistics, and private-sector development across Asia and Africa. Previously, she led technical delivery for Triple Line Consulting’s Trade & Industry portfolio, working on projects for the World Bank, IFC, UNIDO, UKAid, and TradeMark Africa. Through her graduate coursework at Johns Hopkins, she has developed advanced skills in econometrics, machine learning, and policy analysis, and is proficient in STATA and Python. She holds an MSc in Economic Policy from SOAS and a BSc in Economics from LSE, University of London.





Nadine Argott




Nadine Argott is currently pursuing her Master’s Degree in Data Analytics and Policy at Johns Hopkins. She brings strong skills in R and data visualization, with a keen focus on energy policy and affordability. Nadine has developed solid statistical modeling and data analysis skills, and she is eager to contribute her expertise at the 2026 AAP Hackathon. You can connect with Nadine on LinkedIn and GitHub.



Akshay Delity
JP Furman

title: Hackathon Teams
text:
Social and Economic Justice
This theme examines how institutions can reduce disparities in access, outcomes, and treatment across health, justice, education, and employment. It looks for biased processes and bottlenecks that quietly shape inequity, and considers how transparency, accountability, and community co-design can shift both performance and perception. The narrative is about building systems that not only function better but also feel fair, respectful, and responsive to those they serve.
Jeanette Perthel
Lauren Wilmoth
Arya Nair
Kristin Bruce
Brian Powers

title: Hackathon Teams
text:
Democracy and Misinformation
The focus here is on safeguarding civic participation by improving information integrity and voter understanding amid polarized media and digital manipulation. It considers interventions like source labeling, content provenance, bot detection, and neutral issue summaries, aiming to increase knowledge without overwhelming or biasing users. The broader arc is a democratic ecosystem where rules are clear, data privacy is respected, and citizens can make informed choices with confidence.
Josh Gamble


Zhiquan Jiang




Zhiquan Jiang is a Master’s student in Applied Economics at Johns Hopkins University and holds a bachelor’s degree in International Studies – International Business from the University of California, San Diego. She focuses on quantitative analysis and econometric methods, and has experience using STATA, R, and Python for data modeling and analysis. Zhiquan looks forward to contributing her analytical skills and collaborating with teams to explore data-driven solutions at the Data Analytics and Policy Hackathon.



Qikai Zhou
Samuel Towler


Agung Putra




Agung Putra is a Johns Hopkins University graduate student pursuing an M.A. in Government in the Kreiger School of Arts & Sciences Advanced Academic Program. He earned his B.A. in Political Science and minored in Business Law at the University of Southern California. Agung is from Philadelphia and is excited to learn more about data analytics and attend his first hackathon.

title: Hackathon Teams
text:
Policy Evaluation and Public Trust
This theme is about closing the loop between policy promises and lived outcomes through rigorous yet practical evaluation and feedback. It emphasizes citizen-relevant metrics, lightweight data pipelines, and iterative improvements that are visible in everyday interactions with public services. The narrative highlights how clear, accessible reporting can turn evaluation into a trust-building practice that demonstrates competence and progress over time.


Yutan Zhang




Yutan Zhang recently completed an M.S. in Applied Economics at Johns Hopkins University and is based in Washington, DC. Her background is in applied econometrics and policy evaluation, with a focus on health and labor policy, drawing on insights from behavioral economics.



Jie Zhou
Zhuocheng Yan
Yutong Li
Dan Wang

title: Organizers
text:
Collin Paschall
Collin Paschall is the faculty director of the M.S. in Data Analytics and Policy at Johns Hopkins University, where he leads program strategy and curriculum development. His work focuses on preparing students to drive data-informed decision-making in the public sector. Dr. Paschall teaches courses spanning statistics, machine learning, artificial intelligence, research design, and the politics of expertise and policy implementation. A political scientist by training, he earned his Ph.D. from the University of Illinois and holds a J.D. from George Washington University.





Chris Kromphardt
At Johns Hopkins, Christopher Kromphardt is the Assistant Program Director and lecturer for the MS in Data Analytics and Policy program.
Kromphardt’s research focuses on how citizens view the performance and legitimacy of judicial institutions, how judicial institutions make decisions, and the design and evaluation of experiential learning activities. Kromphardt has published in the Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion, Journal of Information Technology & Politics, Journal of Law and Courts, Justice System Journal, and Marquette University Law Review, among other outlets. His research has been cited in a report by the Project on Government Oversight to the Presidential Commission on the Supreme Court of the United States and in an amicus curiae brief from the Association of American Medical Colleges in Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard. His writing for public audiences has appeared in Slate and The Washington Post.
Kromphardt has taught courses on public policy, research methods and research design, constitutional law, and American politics.
Kromphardt received his PhD from the University of Alabama in Political Science.





Alan Lujan
At Johns Hopkins, Alan Lujan is a Program Coordinator and lecturer for the MS in Applied Economics program. In this role, he supports the administration and coordination of instruction while continuing to pursue his research interests.
Lujan is a computational economist specializing in quantitative macroeconomics and structural econometrics, with particular interests in household finance and inequality. He received his PhD in Economics from The Ohio State University in 2023, where his research focused on developing and applying advanced computational methods to address critical issues in macroeconomics, particularly those related to household financial decision-making and the distribution of wealth.
